STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 26, 2020
Lori Schultz
Newaygo/Lake County DHHS
PO Box 640
White Cloud, MI 49349
RE: License #: CP620201323
Newaygo/Lake County DHHS
1018 Newell St
White Cloud, MI 49349
Dear Ms. Schultz:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
August 25, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Courtney Atkins at (517) 599-3667.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Stephanie Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from the removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of four Initial Service Plans reviewed was submitted after the 30-day required
timeframe.
Two of twenty-eight Updated Service Plans reviewed was submitted after the
required timeframe.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Interim Inspection Report with an
approved CAP dated 10/25/2019.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports
At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, an
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors),
and provided to the foster care provider.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed lacked the required medical passports.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
4

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Types and Timeframes: FTMs must occur within the required
timeframes as outlined in policy.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have the required FTM’s
documented as required by policy.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Interim Inspection Report with an
approved CAP dated 10/25/2019.
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including:
 Child fatality.
 Change in caseworker or organization.
 Change in parent contact information.
 Foster care transfer to adoption.
 Change in placement.
 Temporary break from placement.
 Program or case closing.
One of eight foster care files were reviewed. One of four cases that required an
action summary lacked the documentation as required by policy.
FOM 722-09 Foster Care – Updated Service Plan Supervisory Approval
Case service plan approval process required the foster care
supervisor to:
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
Five of twenty-eight Updated Service Plans reviewed were approved after the
required 14-day timeframe.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Interim Inspection Report with an
approved CAP dated 10/25/2019.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
Signatures:
5

When competed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older in the case
of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed lacked the required caregiver signatures,
which would indicate their involvement in the plan development.
One of three independent living files reviewed lacked the youth’s signatures.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Interim Inspection Report with an
approved CAP dated 10/25/2019.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was provided technical assistance in the area of supervisory approval of
service plans. It was recommended the supervisors develop a tracking method when
returning reports for “re-work” as the caseworkers were not re-submitting them
timely resulting in late supervisor approval on service plans.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period in response to the 2019 interim audit.
Staff were interviewed throughout the inspection. All staff interviewed reported
feeling very supported not only by their direct supervisor but by all of management.
Staff had a good understanding of the job expectations and internal agency
procedures. Management reported the agency has had significant stability in staffing
over the past year which has helped the agency obtain and maintain consistency in
caseworker assignment.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
6

Stephanie Meeuwenberg Date
